Staff Writer P Attinger Author email Feb 12, 2025 Feb 12, 2025 Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email COURTESY/TOURIST DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL-VISIT SEBRING Outlines for improvements at Lake June Park would include more boat ramps and a larger boat dock, along with increased parking (not shown) by paving the dirt and grass portions of the parking area, organizing it for a greater number of visitors. Other improvements would include upgraded bleachers at the ballfields and restrooms for the park. COURTESY/TOURIST DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL-VISIT SEBRING Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save The Town of Lake Placid wants help from Visit Florida to improve Lake June Park. Recently, Town Administrator Charlette Rodriguez and Town Engineer Dennis Murray spoke to the Tourist Development Council Board of Directors, asking for their support to get a sport facility improvement grant. They want to upgrade the parking, boat ramps and amenities at Lake June Park to make it more feasible for big events. According to the application, the reimbursable grant would refund the town up to 75% of the maximum funding of $30,000, once work has been completed. The list of events already taking place at Lake June Park includes the Lake June Boat races, accounting for more than 200 room-nights for that weekend and up to 1,300 spectators and 20 food and merchandise vendors. Murray told the TDC Board how the park has approximately 15 acres of space to build. It currently has parking, picnic tables, ball fields, soccer fields, a boat ramp and dock, restrooms, playground equipment and a large grassy area. However, as Rodriguez and Murray pointed out, the town needs to have a study done for a master plan to enhance the facility and make Lake Placid more of a sports tourism destination. Right now, parking only consists of grass and shell surface with no lined spaces. Town officials want to see paved parking and a larger boat dock. They also want to see overhead lighting, improved restrooms and at least eight pickleball courts. Debra Worley, representative on the Board for Lake Placid, said the last master plan for this park dates back to 2006, almost 20 years ago. Town staff, she said, have been working on upgrades to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990. With some orange groves being sold off around the park, she said this is a chance to expand it. â€œItâ€™s time to do it,â€ Worley said. â€œDifferent sports have come into play. We havenâ€™t had a plan in a long time. We need professional advice.â€ In the grant application, town staff stated that a master plan would provide clear vision and a structured approach to improvements, as well as a means to foster and increase community involvement in the process and the park itself. The plan could help them better allocate funds and resources for improvements, the grant application states, and would provide a long-term plan to sustain growth and improvements at the site. Recently, the town hosted the Southern Outlaw Drag Boat Association, from Sept. 7-8, 2024. It brought in more than 100 visitors and overnight guests, the grant application states. Plans in place now would bring the race back this year (2025) and in 2026. Other plans will bring a paddleboard endurance race to Lake June in December 2025. Right now, Lake June Park can park 100 trailers and vehicles for 40-foot-long boats on a temporary basis, on the grass. The drag boat event also needs a 10,000-square-foot staging area for vendors and food trucks, the grant application states. Right now, the park has just one boat launch, no overhead lights and no hookups on site for power. Improving the boat launch area would be the first phase, with an additional launch ramp and a larger dock, approximately 5,000 square feet, as well as lighting and restroom expansion. The second phase would involve reconditioning the ball fields, further lighting improvements and improving the concession stand and bleachers, as outlined in the application. Meet The Town of Lake Placid Elected Officials â€‹ The Town of Lake Placid, Florida has a Mayor/Council form of government, where the Mayor and four Town Council Members play a crucial role in decision-making. The Council also appoints one Council Member as Vice Mayor. The Mayor, and Council Members are elected by the citizens of the Town of Lake Placid for a four-year term. As per the town's charter, the Mayor is responsible for the town's administrative and executive functions. The Mayor presides over all Council meetings and has the power to cast the deciding vote in case of a tie. On the other hand, the Vice Mayor is elected by the Council Members annually and assists the Mayor in carrying out the Town's responsibilities. The Council Members, whom the citizens of the town elect, play a vital role in developing the Town's policies and ensuring that the Town's interests are well-represented. They serve for a term of four years, and their contributions are valuable in shaping the Town's future. â€‹ The Town Council meets at 5:30 p.m. on the 2nd Monday of each month* in the Lake Placid Government Center, Council Chambers, 1069 US Highway 27 N, Lake Placid, Florida. The Town Council also serves as the Lake Placid Community Development Agency (CRA) Board. The CRA Board meets prior to the Regular Town Council Meeting Quarterly at 5:30 p.m. *Special meetings and/ or workshops may be held on additional dates and will be noticed. â€‹ Elected Officials can be contacted by calling the Lake Placid Government Center at 863-699-3747 and leaving a message, Town staff will ensure that any message received is forwarded to the officialÂ  or contact by emailing the Mayor or Council Members emails located below. Mayor John Holbrook has been serving the Town of Lake Placid since 1998. Mayor Holbrook served on the Town Council and has served three terms as Mayor. The Loop is a premium vacation destination for recreation, not just in Summer and Winter, but all year long. Offering four distinct seasons, most visitors to June Lake are outdoor enthusiasts seeking activities in the Great Outdoors. Winter recreation in The Loop includes downhill skiing and snowboarding on June Mountain, also known as â€œCaliforniaâ€™s Family Mountainâ€ where kids as young as 12-years and under can ski or snowboard for FREE! There is also cross country skiing and snowmobile groomed trails available nearby. In the warmer months, the snow-capped mountains melt away, transforming our lakes and valleys into a summer playground for recreation enthusiasts who enjoy camping, RVing, hiking, biking, backpacking, horseback riding, fishing and boating. The Loop, with its four pristine alpine lakes is a fishermenâ€™s paradise! Fishing season opener, known as Fishmas happens on the last Saturday in April. There are four Marinas in the Loop with boat rentals and launches. There are six trailheads in the Loop with varying distances and levels of difficulty so there is something for everyone. The list of outdoor activities and recreation is limited only by your imagination! Her most recent position prior to her arrival at the lake was as the Athletic Director at The Crosby at Rancho Santa Fe. She is an East County native, with a degree in Communication from San Diego State, and is a Certified Park and Recreation Executive. Youâ€™ll spot her around the campground and lake wearing a smile and her pink steel-toed boots that Earl picked out for her. Sherry Recreation Coordinator Sherry joined the lake as our Recreation Coordinator in October of 2019 after working in both animal welfare and community recreation. She studied Recreation Management and Wildlife Biology at the University of Vermont. She joined the team at Lake Jennings to share her love of water and wildlife with the public. One of her favorite things about the lake is driving into the campground on Saturday mornings to the smell of bacon and coffee over the campfire! On the weekends, she splits her time between the campground and the lake. She looks forward to bringing more fun events to Lake Jennings! Shirley Office Assistant Shirley has been with Lake Jennings since March 2025. A San Diego State University graduate with a degree in Japanese, she has a passion for learning and different cultures. She finds peace and tranquility at the lake, enjoying its views, trails, and relaxing atmosphere. Shirley appreciates working in such a serene and picturesque environment. Ray Maintenance Ranger Ray joined us here at Lake Jennings in June 2020. For 25 years, Ray was the owner of the Dub Spot Custom V.W. & Porsche Shop. He also worked at the Green Door CafÃ© in La Jolla. You may recognize Ray as a local Baseball Coach as well. Ray is often driving the dump truck around the lake waving at everyone he sees. Ray enjoys that the lake is a â€œgetawayâ€ in the city. Everyone here is happy to be here and that makes him feel good about being here. Danielle Maintenance Ranger Danielle joined Lake Jennings in October 2021 as an Assistant Recreation Ranger and became a full-time Maintenance Ranger in 2025. A Ventura College alum with a background in math, geology, and years with the Boy Scouts of America, she loves meeting guests, swapping fishing tips, and enjoying early sunrises. Youâ€™ll often find her in Siesta Cove, likely with a few trout on a stringer. Glenn Assistant Maintenance Ranger Glenn joined our team as an assistant maintenance ranger in December 2021. Coming to us with a wide range of experience, Glenn grew up farming in the Midwest, dedicated twenty years to engineering in the U.S. Navy, and worked many years in commercial construction. Glenn loves the lake because it is a great place to get away from the big city without having to travel a long way. Depending on the weather, Glenn enjoys hiking or lounging in the shade and enjoying the views! Garry Assistant Maintenance Ranger Garry joined the Lake Jennings team in May 2024. He attended Granite Hills High School and studied ornamental horticulture at Cuyamaca College. Before Lake Jennings, Garry spent ten years in public works at Viejas, and also worked at UCSD and the Alpine Special Treatment Center. He enjoys the lake as a nearby escape, especially fishing with his family and observing wildlife. An animal lover, Garry has several pets and volunteers at the Feral Cat Coalition. Heâ€™s also an avid fan of H.P. Lovecraft. Cole Assistant Maintenance Ranger Cole joined the Lake Jennings team in October 2021. Cole is a student at Grossmont College and has joined us from his previous occupation as a valet driver at Four Points Little Italy. Cole loves anything and everything that has to do with the outdoors, so itâ€™s safe to say youâ€™ll probably find him weed whacking and maintaining the campground. Coryn Guest Service Associate Coryn joined Lake Jennings as a Guest Service Associate in February 2024. A Grossmont College student planning to transfer to a university, she loves the lakeâ€™s beauty, wildlife, and peacefulness. Coryn enjoys birdwatching and hopes to protect wildlife and work in national parks one day. Auheen Guest Service Associate Auheen, a biology student at Grossmont College, joined Lake Jennings in June 2025, bringing creativity, enthusiasm, and a love of nature to every part of lake life. Outside of work, she enjoys art, music, and spending time outdoors. Always happy to help or chat, Auheen loves making every visitorâ€™s experience at the lake memorable. Jenny Guest Service Associate Jenny loves wildlife, native plants and birds so much that she was excited to make Lake Jennings her office in 2025. Shayla loves exploring trails, observing wildlife, and enjoying boat outings. Her passion for the outdoors and camping reflects her deep connection to nature. Sebastian Assistant Recreation Ranger Sebastian joined Lake Jennings in December 2024, drawn by his love for fishing and the outdoors. Before joining the lake, he spent a year at McDonaldâ€™s. In his free time, Sebastian balances basketball, school, and relaxing by the lake. Vincent Assistant Recreation Ranger Vincent joined Lake Jennings in July 2025, bringing curiosity and a positive attitude to the team. Stephen Dockhand Stephen joined Lake Jennings in July 2022 as a dockhand. Jesse Dockhand Jesse was hired as a Dockhand at the lake in October 2021. A U.S. Navy veteran with a background in aviation electronics and leadership studies at Grossmont College, he brings decades of experience from Sanyo Electric, John Deere, and GKN Aerospace. Scott loves the lakeâ€™s scenery, wildlife, and connecting with guests, whether through fishing, hiking, or capturing photos of happy anglers. Kenny Campground Host Kenny moved to Lake Jennings from Louisiana in May of 2025. He graduated from Del Gado College in New Orleans and worked in Mechanical Engineering for over 35 years. He enjoys the morning hikes on the campground loop trail and appreciates that it feels like an oasis in an urban setting! Josh Campground Host Josh joined Lake Jennings as a Park Host in October 2024. He previously served as a camp host at Lake Piru and Lake Casitas and studied computer science at Moorpark Community College. Josh enjoys the lakeâ€™s peacefulness, scenic views, and wildlife, especially the variety of bird species. Outside of work, he loves spending time with his wife and their beagle, Ziva, and is always ready for his next sushi adventure. Willie Campground Host Willie joined Lake Jennings in March 2025, bringing decades of experience from his long tenure in the U.S. Navy. An Ashford University graduate, he enjoys the lakeâ€™s stunning views and the professionalism of the staff. In his free time, Willie loves fishing, helping others, and taking walks around the lake. He is always eager to connect with the community and embrace the outdoors. Sonya Campground Host Sonya brings a love for the lake, the outdoors, and a strong spirit of service. With over six years of honorable service in the US Military, she now balances her studies at the University of Maryland Global Campus with campground life. Previously a host in Texas, Sonya enjoyed leading bird-watching classes and sharing her passion for nature. Bud, Retiree Former Assistant Recreation Ranger Bud was a Lake Jennings staple. He worked at the lake part time for over 30 years. He also worked in publishing with the Union Tribune for 20 years and spent some time working in ship yards and on aircraft before that. He was a San Diego local who attended SDSU and studied political science and biology. He deeply loved the lake because of the rewarding experience it brings to all. He enjoyed teaching others to respect nature and explaining different techniques and bait for catching fish! Bud passed away in 2022. He will be sorely missed by many. Earl, Retiree Former Maintenance Ranger Earl was known for his jolly personality and rainbow suspenders, you couldnâ€™t miss him around the campground! He was also a volunteer firefighter with the Julian Cuyamaca Fire Protection District and spent 14 years of experience as a Ranger at Lake Cuyamaca where he also served as the Reservoir Keeper. He was with Lake Jennings from December 2008 to April 2021, and was a Senior Chief in the U.S. Navy in his younger years. Earl passed away in 2024 but his legacy and shining personality lives on at Lake Jennings Campground through his rainbow bench as colorful as the man himself. Tim, Retiree Maintenance Ranger Ranger Tim worked at Lake Jennings for 10 years. He was our resident tractor expert, and is excellent at felling trees. Tim gave up his job as a transportation manager for a nationwide distribution company to come back to nature at Lake Jennings. He loved camping and fishing at the lake and turned that love into a career! Heâ€™s now enjoying the retired life and still loving the outdoors.
